text: The Fertility Medical Director Prof Geeta Nargund has highlighted the significant disparities in the payments made by the NHS Clinical Commissioning Groups for fertility treatment. Prof Nargund stressed the need for a national tariff to ensure equitable access to the treatment across different regions. CCGs pay clinics to provide fertility treatment under the NHS, but the payments per cycle can vary widely.Data collected in 2014-15 by campaigning group Fertility Fairness using the Freedom of Information Act revealed that the CCG payments for fertility treatment ranged from less than £3,000 to over £6,000 per cycle. Such inconsistencies create an imbalance in the availability of treatment for women and couples across the country. According to Prof Nargund, introducing a national tariff would allow CCGs in certain areas to offer more treatment options for patients. She suggested that economists and CCGs should collaborate to determine a fair and realistic payment cap which could potentially fall between £3,000 and £3,500 per cycle. A national tariff would ensure that individuals seeking fertility treatment have equal access to services regardless of their geographic location. Professor Nargund's call for a fair price system aims to address the existing disparities and promote fairness and equality in the provision of fertility treatments within the NHS. A national tariff for fertility treatment would also ease the financial burden on the patients. As suggested by Prof Nargund, setting a reasonable cap per cycle would provide a clearer framework for both the clinic and patient, making the process more transparent. Furthermore, it would enable the CCGs to allocate their budgets more effectively, ensuring that resources are distributed equitably and efficiently. As the debate between economists and CCGs continues, finding a consensus on the fair and realistic payment cap will be crucial in establishing a universal and affordable fertility treatment plan to empower more people and couples to pursue their dreams of starting a family.

text: Title: Australian election results remain undecided, unelected Parliament a possibilitySubtitle: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull was confident despite the unspecified outcomeDate: 13 September 2023The Australian Federal Election took an unexpected turn on Tuesday as the counted votes continued, leaving the final result too close to call. Despite the uncertainty, Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull expressed confidence in his ability to secure the required number of seats for a majority government. His office denied claims made by opposition leader Bill Shorten, who claimed that Turnbull planned to call a snap election in the event of an inconclusive result.Australia faces the possibility of a "hung parliament" if neither of the two main political parties manages to reach the mandatory 76-seat majority. As of the latest analysis of Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), with almost 80% of the votes tallied, 10 seats remain undecided. The current projections of ABC indicate 68 seats for the Liberal-National coalition leading, 67 seats for the Labor Party and five seats allocated to Independents and minor parties. It is expected that the final result may not be determined for several more days. This delay is due to the large volume of absentee and postal votes which are still being processed. Minister Turnbull acknowledged that there are important lessons to be learned from this election. The ongoing uncertainty and potential for a hung parliament tack on the divisive nature of the race and the desire for change among Australian voters.As the situation continues to evolve and more votes are counted, Australia remains on the edge awaiting a definitive outcome that will shape the country's political landscape for years to come.

The findings therefore provide insight into the irregularities around the ticketing for the 2016 Olympic Games and shed light on the questionable actions of those involved. text: Former Tunisian President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali, who held power for over two decades, faced a mixed legacy during his rule and subsequent downfall. While credited with bringing stability and some economic prosperity to Tunisia, his tenure was marked by the suppression of political freedoms. He moved up the ranks of Tunisian security establishment and served as the country's ambassador to Poland in the early 1980s. In 1987, he became Prime Minister and shortly after executed a bloodless palace coup, overthrowing Tunisia's first post-independence ruler, Habib Bourguiba. During his presidency, Ben Ali implemented policies focused on economic development, foreign investment and the improvement of Tunisia's infrastructure. Under his rule, the country experienced economic growth with a noticeable growth of the middle class. The benefits of this growth were however not evenly distributed, leading to grievances and social inequality. While some viewed Ben Ali’s regime as a model of stability in a region plagued by political unrest, others criticized his government for widespread corruption, nepotism, and human rights violations. In 2011, Tunisia witnessed a popular uprising known as the Arab Spring, triggered by the self-immolation of a fruit vendor named Mohamed Bouazizi who protested against police harassment and economic hardships. The protests spread rapidly throughout the country, demanding an end to Ben Ali's regime and calling for democratic reforms. Faced with massive public discontent and growing protests, Ben Ali fled the country on January 14, 2011 seeking refuge in Saudi Arabia. Six months later a Tunisian court found him and his wife, Leila Trabelsi, of embezzlement and misuse of public funds in absentia. They were sentenced to 35 years in prison.The expulsion of Ben Ali marked a turning point in Tunisia's history, inspiring similar uprisings throughout the Arab world. However, the country faced significant challenges in its transition to democracy, including political instability, economic difficulties and extremist threats. Despite the criticisms surrounding Ben Ali's rule, Ben Ali left a lasting impact on Tunisia and its trajectory. The country continues to grapple with the ongoing struggle for democratic consolidation and socio-economic development.

In response to the UK government's request to estimate the number of jobs linked to exports in Scotland, the institute used the most recent data from the Scottish government for 2013. However, he cautioned against assuming that the rise of the prison population during the same period caused the increase of crime.Dame Anne Owers, the Chief Inspector of Prisons for England and Wales, also weighed in on the matter. text: Every poll throughout the campaign put the Conservatives ahead - and that was indeed the result.The final polls were fairly accurate about the Conservative and Lib Dem shares. It was Labour where they were uniformly wrong. They also overestimated UKIP and the SNP.Survation were closest to the actual result. Kantar Public's numbers were also reasonably good.YouGov's final poll, like most of the others, seriously underestimated Labour. Prior to that, they had been suggesting a closer race. They also had a separate seat projection model which had been indicating a hung parliament. That had been met with a lot of scepticism but, with hindsight, was pretty accurate.In the final weeks of the campaign, the polls were often criticised for being "all over the place". It's true that they were pointing to very different outcomes.That variation clearly made it difficult to interpret what they were saying. It's surely better, though, that they had different numbers than that they were all wrong in exactly the same way. If you're looking for consistent accuracy then opinion polls are probably not for you.Pollsters are also sometimes accused of herding - deliberately manipulating their figures so they all say the same thing. That accusation can't be levelled at this election.In 2015 the polls went wrong because their samples were not representative of the electorate - they contained too many Labour voters. They also failed to estimate the difference in turnout rates between different age groups - they overestimated turnout among young voters.The pollsters who were furthest from the actual result this time were those, like ICM and ComRes, who had taken the strongest measures to try to rectify the problem from 2015. Survation made no significant changes to their methodology and came out on top.It looks as though the errors this time were caused, at least in part, by fighting the last war.We'll never know the exact figures for turnout among young voters - it's a secret ballot remember - but YouGov's post-election estimate puts it at 57% for 18-19 year olds and 59% for 20-24 year olds.That's lower than for older voters but considerably higher than estimates for young voters in 2015.We can also see that the places where the number of voters increased the most were generally those with young populations. The assumption made by some pollsters that young turnout would continue to under-perform was probably wrong.

The ombudsman criticized the police for their failure to send out a warning about the bomb. Following this critique, NIRPOA wrote a letter of complaint to Justice Minister David Ford expressing its concerns over the findings of the report. The incident occurred in August 1988 when a booby-trap device detonated at 38 Kildrum Gardens in the Creggan area of Derry. Regrettably two individuals, identified as Eugene Dalton (55) and Sheila Lewis (60) lost their lives in the blast. The decision of NIRPOA to challenge the historical investigations suggests their disagreement with the report's conclusions and potential implications for former police officers involved in the case. The Association’s action highlights the ongoing tensions surrounding the inquiry into historical incidents from the troubled past of Northern Ireland and the complex legal and moral issues surrounding such investigations. The absence of a warning was widely condemned and a failure to protect the lives of innocent civilians.The ombudsman's report sheds light on this specific incident, but it has also exposed broader shortcomings within the police force during that time. The investigation aimed to reconcile the past and promote truth and justice for all victims of the Troubles in Northern Ireland, regardless of their background or affiliation. However, the challenge of NIRPOA reflects concerns over the potential impact of these investigations on retired officers. They argue that the actions of individual officers must be seen in the context of the challenging and volatile environment in which they worked and the ongoing threat of terrorist organizations. The issue further underscores the complexity of addressing historical injustices while navigating the delicate balance between accountability and reconciliation. The outcome of the challenge of NIRPOA and the larger debate surrounding the historical investigations have significant implications for the justice system and the healing process in Northern Ireland.

"Ratifying the results of Russian aggression in Ukraine would buy you some short term stability," said Mr Vershbow, when asked about the possibility that Mr Trump might accept the Kremlin calling the shots in eastern Europe in return for better relations. "But I think it would create a much more unstable situation in Europe, encourage the Russians to continue to press forward for some kind of Yalta 2 with a new division of Europe into spheres of influence, which I think would bring back some of the instability we saw in previous decades. "Prior to his Nato role, Mr Vershbow was US ambassador to Moscow from 2001-2005.Acquiescing to further Russian operations in Ukraine (which is not a Nato member) might send a signal that the president-elect effectively recognises Russia's right to dominate certain neighbouring states, many Nato decision-makers feel.They fear also a possible knock-on effect in former Soviet republics that are now part of Nato (and indeed the European Union), the Baltic republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. "There must be absolutely no doubt about the imperative of defending and protecting Nato territory. There must be no discussion or deals about zones of influence, new Yaltas," says Gen Shirreff, "because that strikes right at the heart of what Nato is about".

text: As discussed by the Cochrane Review: Vitamin D shows promise for reducing severe asthma attacksSate: 17 December 2023An independent review conducted by renowned research body Cochrane has revealed that vitamin D supplementation may significantly reduce the risk of serious asthma attacks. The analysis of nine clinical trials found that supplementation with vitamin D lowered the rate of asthma attacks that require hospital admissions or visits to the emergency room. Additionally, it decreased the need for steroid treatment among asthma patients. However, the researchers caution that further study is required to determine whether the beneficial effects of vitamin D are limited to patients who are vitamin D deficient. Official advice can not be provided until more comprehensive studies are conducted. Patients are advised to consult their general docs (GPs) or pharmacists before considering vitamin D supplementation. Dr. Adrian Martineau, the lead author of the Cochrane Review, stated that vitamin D supplementation reduced the risk of serious asthma attacks without adverse side effects. The review concluded that the supplementation decreased the occurrence of severe asthma attacks from 6% to 3% and the frequency of asthma attacks require steroid treatment from 0.44 to 0.28 attacks per person per year. The review did not reveal any improvement in lung function or other daily asthma symptoms associated with vitamin D intake. The research involved seven trials with 435 children and two studies with 658 adults over a period of up to one year. Although these trials primarily focus on adults with mild or moderate asthma, additional studies are necessary to assess the impact on children and individuals with severe asthma. Professor Martineau clarified that ongoing analyses are in progress and awaiting results in the coming months. It is worth noting that Public Health England suggested that everybody should consider taking vitamin D supplements during the autumn and winter due to insufficient sunlight exposure. An extensive evidence review suggested that individuals over the age of 1 should consume 10 micrograms of vitamin D daily to support bone and muscle health. Additionally, individuals with diets lacking vitamin D should consider taking 10 micrograms supplements during the winter months. However, the dose of Vitamin D used in the clinical trials mentioned in the Cochrane review was significantly higher, from 25 to 50 micrograms per day. Asthma affects about 5.4 million individuals in the UK, accounting for one in eleven people. There are 185 hospital admissions and three deaths attributed to this respiratory condition each day. Dr. Erika Kennington, head of research at Asthma UK, acknowledged the promise of the research but emphasized that further evidence is needed to definitively establish whether vitamin D supplementation can effectively reduce asthma attacks and symptoms. In conclusion, the Cochrane review suggests that vitamin D supplementation may reduce the risk of severe asthma attacks and reduce the need for steroid treatment. However, additional studies are needed to determine the effectiveness of vitamin D for various patient groups.

"Another user, Kristyn Ann, wrote: "This is utterly ridiculous. Shameful really. "I think I'll be taking photos with my daughters, female friends and colleagues instead. "Not everyone disagreed with the sentiment by Ms Gregoire Trudeau, a mother-of-three and former entertainment news reporter.Her post received 11,000 likes and 2,300 "hearts" - more than the angry and crying face emojis that can also be used to react to posts on the social network. "Ma'am, despite the backlash you're taking over this, I'd like to say thank you for the spirit of inclusion it was clearly meant in," wrote user Ian Stumpf.Emily Herbert wrote:  "I can't believe the backlash!! It seems so few men are standing by us in our fight for equality. It is always nice to appreciate the ones that are. "Ms Gregoire Trudeau also responded to people's comments on her original post. "Well, now we're having a conversation! Thanks to everyone for your feedback and pics! Love it," she wrote a few hours later.Her message included a promotion for her International Women's Day events with Plan International Canada, a charity, and Equal Voice, an organisation dedicated to electing more women to political office.Ms Gregoire Trudeau added: "Our goal is gender equality, and fighting for it is going to require men and women working together - raising our boys and girls to make a difference, hand-in-hand. This is about recognising that we should be allies on this journey. "An outspoken advocate for gender equality, Mr Trudeau has repeatedly spoken of himself as a "feminist".

text: In a recent social media post, Sophie Grégoire Trudeau's call for commemorating male allies sparks controversyEdgy is divide over the message by the wife of Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau International Women's Day. But her message urging people to commemorate male friends and their support for women's empowerment sparked a contentious debate among Facebook users on March 8, to encourage her followers to join her in acknowledging the boys and men who empower and respect women. She called for individuals to share images of themselves with their "male ally" using the hashtag #MaleAlliesMatter. Despite her intentions to highlight supportive male figures, the post received mixed reactions from Facebook commenters. While some praised the message and shared their own uplifting experiences, others called Grégoire Trudeau's post "tone deaf" and even "shameful." The critics pointed out that International Women's Day is primarily a day dedicated to celebrating the achievements and struggles of women and raising awareness about gender equality issues. They argued that shifting the focus to male allies undermined the main purpose of the day and diverted attention away from women’s unique experiences and challenges. The controversy surrounding the post centered on the accompanying photo of Grégoire Trudeau and her husband, the Minister of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, holding hands. While some saw the image as a symbol of a supportive partnership, others criticized it as an unnecessary display of privilege and detracting from the experiences of those less fortunate. Gregoire Trudeau's call to recognize male allies reflects a growing conversation around the importance of the male engagement in gender equality and women's rights. Advocates argue that men play a crucial role in challenging patriarchal norms and helping dismantle systemic barriers that hinder gender equality. However, in a complex and nuanced discussion, they feel that International Women's Day should remain a specific celebration of women's voices and achievements, refraining from reducing its significance by including the experiences of male allies. As the debate continues, this news article serves as a reminder of the ongoing conversation around gender equality and the diverse perspectives within feminist activism

text: Since then, ERT has undergone several major overhauls to keep up with fierce private competition.These efforts were not entirely successful, and a fall in the company's ratings in the mid-1990s triggered a long-running debate about its cost and efficiency.Eighty per cent of the company's funding came from a licence fee included in electricity bills, and some of it was sourced from advertising revenue.Many Greeks objected to funding ERT through the licence fee, claiming that the company was too unpopular and too expensive. The broadcaster was also criticised for its openly pro-government reporting, especially since the start of the financial crisis in 2009.At the time of closing, ERT operated three main TV channels and more than a dozen national and local radio stations. ERT World TV catered for the Greek diaspora across the globe.The company's programming included news as well as factual and entertainment programmes. It claimed to broadcast more highbrow programmes - such as world cinema and documentaries - compared to the generally more light-hearted entertainment offered by its privately-owned rivals.The company's audience share in 2013 was relatively low at below 20%, with most Greeks preferring commercial broadcasters.The government's surprise decision to shut down ERT was, however, met with fierce criticism from the public. Even though most agreed that a restructuring and cost-savings were required at the company, its immediate closure was branded "dictatorial" by some.While most Greeks will continue getting their news and entertainment from private TV and radio stations, those in the east and some islands - where signal coverage is poor - may have to rely on Turkish broadcasters across the border.BBC Monitoring reports and analyses news from TV, radio, web and print media around the world. For more reports from BBC Monitoring, click here. You can follow BBC Monitoring on Twitter and Facebook.

text: The Greek public broadcaster ERT has a rich and storied history which can be traced back to the 1930s. The origins of the company can be found in the formation of the National Radio Foundation in Greece during that time. ERT has evolved into a well-established national institution over the course of many decades that commands respect from many parts of the world. Although it was primarily known as a radio broadcaster in its early years, ERT expanded its offerings and entered television programming in the 1960s. At that time it held the distinction of being the sole TV broadcaster in Greece. ERT maintained its monopoly for nearly three decades until the introduction of private television channels in 1989. The introduction of television programming marked a significant milestone in the history of Greek media. It has brought a range of visual content to households across the country and has played a crucial role in shaping the television landscape in Greece. During this period, ERT has been a dominant tv broadcaster and has played a vital role in shaping Greek public opinion and fostering national unity. The institution's enduring legacy and widespread influence have further strengthened its position as an important pillar of the Greek media. The long history of ERT has garnered a devoted following and is infused with a sense of trust and reliability among viewers and listeners. As the time has passed, ERT has continued to evolve and adapt to the changing media landscape. It embraced technological advancements and diversified its programming to cater to a wider audience. ERT is today a respected public broadcaster in Greece, delivering a variety of content across radio, television and online platforms to inform, entertain and educate the Greek population.ERT's resilience and ability to stay relevant in an era of digital media and greater competition among broadcasters are testament to its enduring appeal and importance as a national institution.

Barnet's first shot on target came in stoppage time of the first half, but Mauro Vilhete's effort was comfortably saved by Stanley's loan goalkeeper Marek Rodak. The home side began the second half with determination, as McCartan narrowly fired from 30 yards out. Shortly after, Barnet winger Jamal Campbell-Ryce attempted to save a chip that was easily saved by Rodak. McCartan provided the decisive moment of the game in the 54th minute, curling a 20-yard free kick into the top corner after Billy Kee was fouled on the edge of the area.Barnet's top scorer John Akinde had a golden opportunity to level the score six minutes from time, but saw his unmarked header blocked from 10 yards on the goal line. In the dying minutes of the match, the Stanley substitute Jordan Clark struck the woodwork, adding to the drama. In the end, Accrington Stanley held onto their slender lead and secured a 1-0 victory over Barnet. The match report was provided by the Press Association. As the second half concluded, Accrington Stanley celebrated its 1-0 win over Barnet. Barnet earned a corner in the closing stages of the match, presenting them with a late opportunity to salvage a draw. The tension was palpable as the ball swung into the box but the Accrington Stanley defense managed to clear the danger and thwarts Barnet's hopes of an equalizer. The last whistle blew Accrington Stanley's 1-0 victory. It was a hard-fought and closely contested match, with both teams showing resilience and determination. The result of Accrington Stanley saw Liam McCartan emerged with his brilliantly executed free kick as the hero, which ultimately proved to be the difference between the two sides. The result propelled Accrington Stanley to a valuable three points, consolidating their position in the league table. text: "I was on my way to the grocery store and she stopped me and said, 'I heard you sing,'" Hawkins recalled.Barbara Ann's sister, Rosa Lee Hawkins, soon joined them. The three later discovered they were cousins.The trio was almost known as the Meltones or Little Miss and the MuffetsBut they settled on the Dixie Cups name in 1964 after being discovered by producer and singer Joe Jones.Jones took them to New York where they recorded Chapel of Love, written by Spector, Jeff Barry and Ellie Greenwich.The band came up with the song's unique vocal arrangement on the spot. "When Ellie and Jeff first played Chapel for us, we looked at each other, like, 'You really want us to sing that like that?'" Hawkins told Rolling Stone. "They said, 'Well, how do you want to sing it?' So I said, 'Give us a minute. '"We went in the corner and started singing. We walked back to them and when we sang it the way it was recorded, they were just, 'Wow! That was awesome. '"The song peaked at number 22 in the UK and was later covered by the Beach Boys.The Dixie Cups released further successful records in 1964 and 1965, including You Should Have Seen the Way He Looked at Me, Little Bell and a cover of the New Orleans standard, Iko Iko.But when their record label went out of business, the band's recording career effectively ended.Johnson quit soon after citing management and health concerns, having suffered with sickle cell anaemia. "Because it was the early sixties, we went through a lot as far as race and a whole lot of other things," Hawkins said. "We had a manager who wasn't really in our corner, but there were a lot of good times. "Johnson occasionally rejoined the band for performances, including one at the 2010 New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival.She died of congestive heart failure in a New Orleans hospice on 3 October.The singer is survived by a sister, Ida, and a brother, Howard. A memorial is planned in New Orleans next week. "The world has lost a classy lady, who had a magnificent sense of humour, a radiating smile, and was truly one of the best people we know," wrote the Dixie Cups on their website.Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsEnts, on Instagram at bbcnewsents, or if you have a story suggestion email entertainment.news@bbc.co.uk.

text: In 1964, the Dixie Cups reached a remarkable milestone in their career when they defeated the Beatles by "Love Me Do" from the number 1 spot in the United States with their hit song "Chapel of Love". Co-written by renowned producer Phil Spector, the first single of Dixie Cups sold over a million copies, consolidating their place in music history. The significance of "Chapel of Love" enlarged beyond its commercial success. It was later recognized by the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as one of 500 songs that shaped Rock and Roll and continued to emphasise its impact on popular music. The infectious melody, the joyful lyrics and the vocal harmonies of the Dixie Cups captured the spirit of the era and resonated with audiences around the world. The formation of the Dixie Cups itself is rooted in the vibrant city of New Orleans. It all started when one of the founding members, Joan Marie Johnson, invited Barbara Ann Hawkins to join her in a High School talent show. The two struck a chord and soon a member, Rosa Lee Hawkins, Barbara's sister, welcomed them, completing the vocal trio that would become the Dixie Cups. Their talents and chemistry propelled them to national success and secured their place in music history. The achievement of the Dixie Cups to beat the iconic Beatles from the top slot, coupled with the enduring popularity of the "Chapel of Love" solidified their status as one of the dominant acts of the 1960s and reinforced their place in the annals of rock and roll. The impact of the rise of the Dixie Cups to fame with "Chapel of Love" cannot be overstated. The song was a cultural sensation, capturing the spirit of a youthful romance and becoming an anthem for a generation. Its success pushed the Dixie Cups to the forefront of the music scene, earning them a place alongside other legendary acts of the time.The harmonious vocals and infectious energy of the trio made "Chapel of Love" an instant classic. Its memorable chorus and its upbeat tempo resonated with listeners and became a staple at weddings, parties and oldies radio stations to this day. The song's timeless appeal and lasting popularity continue to introduce new generations to the magic of the Dixie Cups. The Dixie Cups' groundbreaking achievement in taking down the Beatles from the number one spot marked a turning point in their career and solidified their place in music history. They remain a cherished symbol of the 1960s music landscape and a testament to the power of harmony, talent and the magic of finding the perfect pop song.
